title: Zoro is a Descendant of Shimotsuki Ryuma
theoryText: Roronoa Zoro is theorized to be a direct descendant of the legendary samurai Shimotsuki Ryuma through the Shimotsuki Family of Wano Country. This connection is supported by several pieces of evidence: their similar appearance, Zoro's natural affinity for swordsmanship, his ability to master techniques like Hiryu: Kaen (which mirrors Ryuma's dragon-slaying), and the fact that Zoro was deemed worthy to inherit Shusui. The theory suggests that Zoro's lineage explains his exceptional talent and his deep connection to Wano-style swordsmanship.
author: Various One Piece fans
evidencePoints: Physical resemblance between Zoro and Ryuma
Ryuma willingly passes Shusui to Zoro, suggesting recognition
Zoro's later connection to Wano Country
Both use fire-based techniques and similar fighting philosophies
counterArguments: No explicit family connection confirmed in the story
Resemblance could be coincidental or thematic rather than genetic
Many skilled swordsmen exist without being related to Ryuma

title: Thriller Bark is a Fragment of God Valley
theoryText: A popular fan theory suggests that the island serving as the base for Thriller Bark is actually a fragment of the destroyed God Valley. The theory is supported by several connections: both locations are associated with the West Blue, and Captain John (a high-ranking member of the Rocks Pirates who was present at the God Valley Incident) appears as a zombie on Thriller Bark. The theory proposes that after the legendary God Valley Incident, this chunk was all that remained of the island, which Gecko Moria later found and incorporated into his floating fortress.
author: Various One Piece community members
evidencePoints: Both Thriller Bark and God Valley are connected to the West Blue
Captain John's presence on Thriller Bark as a zombie
The mysterious origins of Thriller Bark's island foundation
Timing aligns with Moria's activities in the area
counterArguments: No explicit confirmation in the manga or anime
God Valley is said to have been erased completely
Thriller Bark's island could be from any location

title: Hiryu: Kaen Foreshadows Zoro Cutting Kaido
theoryText: The debut of Hiryu: Kaen in Episode 362 was theorized to foreshadow Zoro's eventual confrontation with Kaido. The technique features a dragon motif and fire, both strongly associated with Kaido. Since Ryuma was famous for slaying a dragon, and Zoro defeats Ryuma using a dragon-themed technique, fans theorized this was Oda foreshadowing Zoro's role in fighting Kaido, the 'Strongest Creature' who takes the form of an Eastern dragon. This theory was partially confirmed when Zoro later used Hiryu: Kaen against Kaido in Episode 1017.
author: One Piece theorists
evidencePoints: Dragon motif in the technique's name and visual effect
Ryuma's legend of slaying a dragon
Zoro inheriting Ryuma's will through Shusui
Later use of the technique against Kaido confirms the foreshadowing
The connection between Wano, dragons, and both Ryuma and Kaido
counterArguments: Initially no confirmation until Wano Arc
Could be interpreted as general power progression rather than specific foreshadowing

title: Shusui's Return Was Always Planned
theoryText: Some fans theorize that Oda always intended for Zoro to temporarily possess Shusui before returning it to Wano, as a narrative device to strengthen Zoro's connection to Wano Country and the Shimotsuki clan. The theory suggests that Shusui served as a 'placeholder' sword, teaching Zoro to wield a black blade while foreshadowing his eventual journey to Wano. By having Zoro return the national treasure, it demonstrates his growth not just as a swordsman but as a person who respects cultural significance over personal power, while receiving Enma (another legendary blade with ties to his potential heritage) in exchange.
author: One Piece story analysts
evidencePoints: Shusui's cultural significance was emphasized from the beginning
The sword's connection to Wano was always clear
Zoro's return of Shusui shows character growth
Receiving Enma maintains narrative balance (trading one legendary sword for another)
The exchange deepens Zoro's connection to Wano's history
counterArguments: Could be retroactive planning rather than original intention
Oda may have changed plans during serialization
Difficult to prove authorial intent definitively
